I have no idea what I’m doing with my life….But I refuse to be average! So let’s build a portfolio shall we?! (Also indecisive so this may change…)
Dec 17, 2016

Of Course Women are Self-Conscious!

As a teenager I always appeared older than my actual age, even though I was always the youngest amongst my friends. I was tall and I had boobs — both a blessing and a curse these things. Which led to older men being attracted to me, and I loved that! Let’s face it, what teenage girl wouldn’t want a guy in his 20’s attracted to her? (Kylie Jenner I ain’t mad at ya).

Therapy! Therapy is a great thing, it helps you uncover things about yourself you never really thought of and get to the root of your problems, and this is how I realized where my self-consciousness about my body came about.

I was probably about 13 or 14, with boobs, and on the beach with my parents. (I grew up on an island in the Caribbean). I was on my way back to our car, (You literally can park on the sand, a minute walk from the water) and there was this guy walking along checking me out. “Hey beautiful!” of course I blushed. I don’t remember if we had a conversation, but I do remember him asking, “Do you have kids?”, “No..” I responded, “Why do you ask?” I’m thinking it’s because I look mature. He responds, “Because your breast has stretch marks.” I was shocked! I mean, appalled! I have no recollection of what happened next, but this is when I started staring at boobs!

That was when I noticed my boobs, at 14, were not perky, that I HAD to wear a bra at all times. That for all my other friends, bras, were optional. That my friends had full breast, and mines, though big, weren’t full at all! None of my other friends at stretch marks on their breast, (I would try and sneak a peak during gym change time). What was wrong with my breast?! I suddenly became so self-conscious of them. I only wanted to wear push-up bras, which my mother refused to buy because according to her, my boobs were big enough. Then one day after school, we took pictures, I was wearing a thin t-shirt with a non-padded bra. A ‘friend’ zoomed in on my boobs and made fun of them being droopy. Everyone laughed!

I was different, I wasn’t like everyone else. I didn’t fit in with what a young girl was supposed to look like.

A few years later another part of my body was brought to my attention. Again at the beach (you’d think I’d learn my lesson), it was midterms, and there was a beach party. Fun, food, drinks, the works. I wore a bikini. Now I’ll admit, I was never one to have six pack abs, I’ve always had a tummy, ALWAYS, to this day! But I thought I looked cute in my two-piece. I stared at myself in the mirror before leaving, debating whether or not I should take a tank top and wear over it like I usually do. But I thought NO! Got to the beach, had fun in the water, came out to grab a drink and this boy I liked said to me “Wow, Amanda you need to do some sit-ups!”

I went straight back into the water and didn’t come out till everyone was ready to go. Even then I folded my arms in front of me. I mean were they all thinking this about me? Do you understand how hard that knocked my confidence down. Now I not only worried that my boobs were ‘droopy’ but that my stomach was huge. All my friends had flat stomachs. With the exception of the obvious ‘fat’ ones. Thing is about me, my stomach was the only part of my body that was big! I had skinny arms and legs! In fact you could easily span my ankle, something my friends also liked doing.

What came next? Bring on the stretch marks! On the side of my stomach. And no, not those cute light faded stretch marks making their way around Instagram memes “Real men love women with real marks..” I mean the black/dark stretch marks you see from a distance. I hated them! I still do. My ex boyfriend used to call them ‘cheater marks’ in a failed attempt to make me feel good about them. Now at 26, I have new stretch marks around my navel! And I don’t even have kids yet!!! These are supposed to appear when I’m pregnant!!! Talk about jumping the gun!

Then there’s my hair! I am black or Afro-Caribbean as the so-called politically correct term. I have coarse hair that was never long in length. My hair could not go into a ponytail or pom pom as we called it (you know when you pull natural hair into a puff thingy). My mother also refused to straighten my hair, like all my other friends, for fear of it ruining my hair. So surprise, surprise I did it behind her back. She was upset, but I didn’t care. I was constantly teased as a teen for having short hair. Only they didn’t call it short they called it picky hair in the Caribbean.

Again I didn’t look like the other girls, I didn’t have long straight hair, or thick long luscious hair. And yes chemical ruined my hair!

See the theme…..I didn’t look like everyone else, all the girls who had boys liking them, had the opposite of what I had. So of course I was self conscious. Self-conscious teenage girls become self-conscious women! Even in today’s society by trying to break beauty standards and get rid of boxes, they still make boxes. Plus size women are beautiful! Yes! However the women they show, have big boobs, asses, and a tiny waist! What about the women with no ass, big tummy and small boobs, with thick thighs? They don’t fit the ‘Plus size acceptable’ box.

Stretch marks are beautiful! But they show the light faded stretch marks. Black girls should go natural. #NaturalGirls when you look, all you see are girls with thick, luscious/mixed type hair doing ‘length check’. My type of hair wouldn’t grow past my ears, let alone shoulders, so I still don’t fit that ‘non-box’. In fact, that was the main reason for me growing dreadlocks in the first place, so that my hair could be long. The gag is, they’re still not long enough for the time I’ve been growing it. Causing people to ask “Did you cut your hair? It should be longer”…… Oh shut up!

Real bodies aren’t perfect. If a woman has big boobs, chances are fellas gravity takes a toll! And the bigger and heavier they get, the more the skin would stretch causing stretch marks. Though there are amazing bras out there, when they come off, those suckers come down! So don’t you dare body shame a girl with hung boobs! #RespectTheBoobs It’s not easy carrying all this around!

Here’s the thing, some days I LOVE my body, I relish in it. Other days I’m like “Shit, fck, what is that?! How much is a trainer?” And I go on a Pinterest/Instagram/Youtube fitness bender.

We’re surrounded by unrealistic expectations, from men as well as other women! We are held to two standards of beauty as I see it, the ‘Celebrity perfection’ and the ‘box-non-box real perfection’. One is what the ultimate woman should look like, the other is what she may/should realistically look like, but most likely still won’t…..confused? Yeah…

Every woman is different.
Every woman carries her weight differently
Every woman has some kind of issue.

But the question remains; How do we love and accept our flaws, while being ridiculed about them?

Thoughts?
